text: anyone ever had this error before?

Hi there we are getting used to the API, but I have one issue, that I would like to point out, maybe someone can shed some light on it:
Some times we get SSLException for no reason (for any valid request). If we try later (e.g. a minutes) It works. Do you think it is a test account problem? as we are not sending any SSL configurations with our requests.

Hey. I'm having an issue oauthing new users for existing customers to an integration of mine that only requires the `contacts` scope.

For example, I see the following when I try to connect a new user of mine to my integration. If I use one of my old users that I created last year, with the exact same permissions, it works with no issue.

Has there been any recent changes around user roles and permissions in HubSpot?
Hi guys! is someone know how to filter a property that has a multi-select type?
You mean in a search request?
Does anyone know if the batch API is supported for custom objects at this point?
Yes, this occurs when you send too many requests within a 10 second period
<https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/APIs-Integrations/Error-You-have-reached-your-secondly-limit/td-p/269485>
Happy to help as well, if you need more people

Hi, when I read a batch of contacts based on email it returns contacts found by secondary email but in the response that secondary email cannot be found. What property should I include to get this returned? This makes it impossible to correlate the results with the emails provided.

Hi team: Can you have a private KB hosted on Service hub, with an access URL limited in terms of availability for specific pages?

Meaning, can I have a private KB expiring pages a certain amount of time after someone first signs on to that page (changing dynamically by the user)? Let me know.
For the 3/8 TLS change, what's the best way to be notified of significant changes like this?
Hey guys, i had a very lengthy discussion with HubSpot support about a 3rd party integration into our site using the forms API. Does anyone know if there is any alternative to this?
What I've done is add a `usleep(250*1000)` within my loops to add a 250ms delay in between requests that way there's no way I hit the secondly limit.

Ok so I got back to this project. There's an object definition endpoint you hit to define an association.

*`/crm/v3/schemas/{objectType}/associations`*
```{
  "fromObjectTypeId": "2-123456",
  "toObjectTypeId": "contact",
  "name": "my_object_to_contact"
}```
Then, batch association requests will work when you use the `my_object_to_contact`!

Magic :fiestaparrot:

@Levi  you want to have a third party site submit  data to HubSpot, correct? I see 2 options depending on your scenario: use the collected forms option in HubSpot, as long as the form is identified on third party with Form tags this should work. Alternatively, consider reversing the flow, put a HubSpot form on your page using the forms code, and use a workflow to push the data to the third party site
<@UCE3D677X>, it's using pardot to create a cart with our 3000+ part CAD library. And is handled via our CAD managing company.
DM Me if you need more information about the flow and urls
Hi guys, does anyone know on the top of their head what the timeout limit is for the Card API for HubSpot to get the response?

I found the answer. In case anyone was curious, the timeout is 5 seconds. This includes the call to HubSpot's frontend as well, so in reality, the card should respond within perhaps around 3-4 seconds.

Hi Lance - the CRM cards are working fine, but I'm still struggling with understanding what HubSpot apps do and how they work *in general*, regardless of whether they use the custom CRM cards or not.  After much reading, I've come up with the following theory.  Can you tell me if the following statement is accurate?
HubSpot apps get *created* and/or *installed* in your HubSpot account, but they *run* somewhere else.  And when they run, what they're doing is making API calls to HubSpot.

The apps are supposed to run on your local webserver, or in your Wordpress site, or in your Slack window, etc.  This is why HubSpot sometimes refers to apps as "integrations".  An app obtains an authentication token with OAuth and then uses that token to make API requests to a HubSpot account where it is installed (or "connected" as HubSpot sometimes calls it).
Does all of that sound right?  I'm writing that blog article I mentioned to you and want to make sure it's accurate.
